title: New Citi-Commissioned EIU Report Projects Competitiveness of 120 of The World's Major Cities in 2025; São Paulo Most Improved City Globally
summary: Miami, Florida - A new Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) research report, "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities," commissioned by Citi, reveals that São Paulo will surge in global competitiveness between 2012 and 2025. Released today at the New Cities Summit in São Paulo, the report forecasts the competitiveness of 120 cities in 2025 based on their projected ability to attract capital, business, talent and tourists.
tag-1: New Citi-Commissioned EIU Report Projects Competitiveness of 120 of The World's Major Cities in 2025; São Paulo Most Improved City Globally
tag-3: Miami, Florida – A new Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) research report, "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities," commissioned by Citi, reveals that São Paulo will surge in global competitiveness between 2012 and 2025. Released today at the New Cities Summit in São Paulo, the report forecasts the competitiveness of 120 cities in 2025 based on their projected ability to attract capital, business, talent and tourists.
tag-4: São Paulo is the report's most improved city globally and is also the most competitive among cities in Latin America. Its rise in competitiveness is attributed to its young and rapidly growing workforce, ease of maritime access and transportation, strong telecommunications infrastructure and low risk of natural disasters. The city's financial position also remains strong, and it is projected to retain its status as the commercial and financial capital of Brazil in 2025.
tag-5: "It is predicted that almost all global growth over the next 30 years will be in urban areas," said Francisco Aristeguieta, Citi's CEO for Latin America. "Being the engine of global growth, Citi recognizes that urban centers are increasingly investment targets, vying to attract capital, business, talent and visitors. The findings from this report prove that Latin American cities will rise in terms of economic strength, infrastructure and global appeal in the years to come, and we are proud to partner with the region's urban centers as we celebrate our first century in Latin America."
tag-6: São Paulo (joint 36th), Santiago (joint 60th) and Panama City (65th) are forecast to be the most competitive cities in the region in 2025 according to the Index. By 2025, Brazil is one of the most improved countries in terms of competitiveness, with three cities —São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro (76th), Porto Alegre (97th) — improving substantially in overall competiveness in the Index.
tag-7: In addition to São Paulo, the other top movers in Latin America — Santiago and Panama City —also have well-developed infrastructure, robust maritime transport and increased economic strength. Top cities in Latin America also rank highly in terms of global appeal (defined as a city's ability to attract people and businesses from around the world) in 2025.
tag-8: As the second most-competitive city in Latin America, Santiago's future appeal rests on having one of the best 'physical capital' environment's (infrastructure to function and attract businesses and talent) of any city in the region, along with a maturing financial sector as well as an ample and qualified pool of human capital. The city's economic strength will continue to rise by 2025 as the Santiago government remains focused on investment in improving the city.
tag-9: Recognizing the importance of access to and ease of global trade and transport, Santiago's government plans to double the city's airport capacity by 2030, São Paulo will be linked to Rio de Janeiro by a high-speed rail, and Panama City will effectively double its capacity for ships through the city's Logistics and Transport Master Plan.
tag-10: "Urban centers throughout Latin America are expected to significantly improve their competitiveness through 2025," said Leo Abruzzese, the EIU's global forecasting director. "São Paulo's rise signals that Latin American cities are climbing the ladder as they become wealthier, investment increases and infrastructure improves."
tag-11: Globally, New York and London are rated as the world's two most competitive cities in 2025, while Singapore, Hong Kong and Tokyo retain their position as third, fourth and fifth. As the top movers in the report, São Paulo, Incheon and Mumbai will surge in global competitiveness between 2012 and 2025.
tag-12: Cities from the United States, Canada, Australia and Western Europe account for 23 of the top 30 cities in 2025, as they will continue to attract capital, businesses and talent, despite concerns over ageing populations and the lingering impacts of the financial crisis.
tag-13: Citi commissioned the "Hot Spots 2025: Benchmarking the Future Competitiveness of Cities" Index to improve understanding of market competitiveness and to identify where growth, opportunity and talent are likely to be found in the decades ahead. Citi recognizes that competitiveness is about more than growth – especially as urban centers vie for investment, talent, and business. The research builds on the inaugural EIU report "Hot Spots: Benchmarking Global City Competitiveness," commissioned by Citi in 2012.
tag-14: For 200 years, Citi's central mission has been to enable economic progress. With its global footprint, Citi connects clients to the world, working at the center of global trade and capital flows. On the ground in more than 1,000 cities, Citi has a unique perspective on the complexities of the urban environment. Through Citi for Cities and other initiatives, Citi works with clients and public and private sector partners in cities around the world to enhance public services, facilitate commerce, expand financial inclusion and harness advancements in digital, mobile and card technologies.
tag-15: The New Cities Summit is organized by the non-profit New Cities Foundation and will take place from June 4-6 in Auditorio Ibirapuéra, São Paulo. The theme for this year's New Cities Summit is 'The Human City' and the event will cover a diverse range of urban issues including technology, infrastructure, mobility, healthcare, governance, architecture, design and new forms of citizen participation.
